title: foreign aid source of corruption
story: Can I start the ball rolling  And maybe then you’d like to hear from a few readers. The people who can’t get beds in our hospitals, or a place for their kids in the local school. All the while that £billion is being spent on fabulously berserk ­projects in the developing world.To her total credit, Mordaunt has said that our current level of spending on overseas aid is unsustainable. It’s been rising every year. Due to a law passed by the coalition government, we have to spend . per cent of our income on aid to the Third World each year.So right now we spend just under £billion. And where does this money go  No less than  per cent of it is siphoned off to global outfits like that most useless of organisations, the United Nations.This is the body which sent out some dimbo Australian envoy to tick off our Government about economic policy. An organisation which elected Saudi Arabia on to its Women’s Rights Commission. An anti-Western and rabidly anti-Israeli convocation of leftie Third World thugs with chips on their shoulders.The world would be enormously improvedthe UN was shut down tomorrow. And the rest of it  Some of the stuff you wouldn’t believe. A total of £, went to a project investigating Tibetan verbs. Nope, not kidding.I would assume that “climb” was one of the verbs they were investigating. They use that a lot, over there. Thanks to our overseas aid, someone, ­somewhere is now able to say in Tibetan: “F*** me, is that a yeti  Run away!”Then there’s the £, spent on a scheme to stop Indian schoolchildren imbibing sugary drinks. India itself gives overseas aid and has an income rather bigger than our own. Where is the point Another six-figure sum was spent ­persuading Chinese people not to smoke too much — China! The second richest country in the world.Another one was to help Indian workers cool their work­stations down — this in a country which has its own space programme, for Chrissakes. So much of our money is swallowed up by useless leftie quangos and charities to keep themselves in jobs.Still more is pocketed by despots in the horrible countries they run. It is a source of corruption and dependency. It makes things worse. And when we tried to ert our overseas aid to some of the Caribbean countries stricken by hurricanes we were told we couldn’t — they were too rich!It’s a nonsense and a racket. If I thought our overseas aid, in its current form, really alleviated misery and suffering I’d be all for it. That’s why I agreed with the last secretary of state, Priti Patel, who wanted to give a decent chunk to the Israel Defence Forces, which saves a lot of lives in Syria.So my recommendation would be to end it all NOW. Divert the money into our beleaguered and creaking infrastructure. And when a tragedy occurs overseas — sure, splash the cash.Anyway, Penny — hope I’ve helped by starting the conversation. Over to you, babes.SCOTTISH politician Ross Greer has already been called a “ginger turd” by Piers Morgan, and I don’t think I can improve on that. But it’s his ignorance and stupidity that staggers – rather than his hatred for Great Britain, which is something we’re used to from north of the border.Greer described Winston Churchill as a white supremacist, a mass murderer and a racist, and likened him to Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin. He says he is simply challenging the “myth” of Churchill. No, Ross, you’re not.You’re just pig ignorant, with a very poor grasp of history. Of course Churchill was racist. Just about everybody was of his age at that time.If you can’t see the importance of Churchill to winning the Second World War – against REAL racists, REAL mass murderers – when Britain stood alone, then you lack all sense of context and proportion.The more I think about it, the more I reckon “ginger turd” was an understatement.HERO of the week is the excellent Rachel Riley, who has been speaking out against anti-Semitism. As a consequence, she now needs greater security when she’s doing TV’s ­Countdown. The left-wing Jew-hating trolls have been after her.Rachel,  said: “The more I speak, the more abuse I get, and the more abuse I get, the more I speak. It’s got to the point where I can’t look at my Twitter feed any more. It’s just a constant stream.”She’s pretty clear who is behind it, too.  A lot of the abuse comes from people who sign off with the hashtag JCPM.SO, Labour MP Fiona Onasanya is off to prison. Found guilty in court of lying through her teeth.But the remarkable thing is she’s still going to be paid as an MP while she’s inside. She has refused to resign her seat and so her £, salary will continue to be paid by the rest of us.If you got sent to the nick, do you think your employers would continue to pay your wages  You’d be out on your ear. It’s kind of ­outrageous, no THIS cultural appropriation business is getting out of hand. Marks  Spencer has been slammed by leftie nutters with nothing better to do with their time. For selling a biryani wrap.They say it’s not authentic. Well of course it’s not bleedin’ authentic.  This is the UK, not Mumbai. Singer Katy Perry was attacked for wearing a kimono because she isn’t Japanese.White people in the US get criticised for wearing training shoes or sporting afros – that’s appropriating black culture, apparently. Though I think it was white folks who invented training shoes. Thing is, cultural appropriation is brilliant.It’s the way we have of sharing our respective cultures.  think it’s wonderful that countries outside Europe and the US have “culturally appropriated” democracy, sanitisation, railways, computers and so on. I wish more would do the same.SOMALIA is the most corrupt country in the world, according to a list compiled by a group called Transparency International.Not a great surprise, is it  Nor to see most of the rest of Africa hogging the bottom quarter of the world table.It’s bad governance and corruption that is keeping Africa poor – not colonialism. You can tell that the compilers of the report are lefties, though. Asked what countries were becoming more corrupt recently, they named the US, Hungary and Brazil. All three have elected right-wing governments.A NEW study says that women who wear short skirts are more likely to be ­promoted.The lesson I’d take from this,I were a women, is to wear a short skirt to work. But I don’t think that’s the lesson they mean us to take.I wonderwomen who wear short skirts but have the legs of an obese ­elephant also are more likely to get ­promoted I think that’s the next study for those researchers at the ­University of Surrey.I TOLD you last week that the reason we haven’t had a proper winter yet is that the people who run winter couldn’t agree on stuff.Such as whether it should be a hard winter, with lots of snow, no winter at all or a compromise deal with a backstop of some sleet for a bit.But I understand that on Tuesday the President of ­Winter won an astonishing ­victory and was able to push her deal through.Which was why it immediately snowed like hell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle acu visit london
story: The pregnant Duchess of Sussex cradled her baby bump as she arrived at the Association of Commonwealth Universities, one of her four new patronages.Its been a busy start to the year for the -year-old, with today her sixth engagement in just three weeks.And she will even head to Bristol tomorrow with Prince Harry, , for a seventh engagement to learn about the citys cultural history.But despite her full schedule, the former actress appeared as happy as ever as she was greeted at the University of London today.Wearing a black Givenchy coat and pleated dress, Meghan had her hair pulled back in a bun for the visit.The neat up-do is in contrast to her usual messy bun look that has seen beauty experts seeing a rise in people hoping to mimic the style.Meghan today received a rock stars welcome as students cheered and waved as the royal got out of the car.During her tour, she spoke with students and academics across the ACUs network, which helps support more than  institutions over  Commonwealth countries.She even spoke to a student, Hilary Harawo, a student in Ghana, over Skype.Meghan’s passion about education first became clear when she spoke in Fiji about her own experiences in paying her own way.In the fiery speech, the Duchess of Sussex revealed it was thanks to scholarships and financial aid programs that she was able to attend university, studying theatre and international relations.After being given her new patronages by the -year-old monarch at the start of the year, she has visited each of the charities, as well as joining Prince Harry for two separate engagements.The former actress yesterday headed to the National Theatre, wearing towering £ Aquazzura heels.Its believed the Duchess - who recently revealed she is around six months pregnant - wore the same Very Matilde designer pumps for the debut as she donned during the engagement announcement with Prince Harry in November .Meghan visited her first patronage, Smart Works, on January  this year - even giving fashion tips to those helped by the charity.Just four days later she headed to Birkenhead with husband Prince Harry, who kept a protective arm around his we.It was during this visit that the parents-to-be revealed their baby is due at the end of April or the beginning of May - and that the gender would be a surprise.Two days later, Meghan was cuddling dogs at the animal charity Mayhew - then joined Prince Harry that night at a Cirque du Soleil performance in a dazzling blue dress.And the announcement of the patronages earlier this month signalled Meghans close bond with the Queen, royal experts revealed.Royal expert Richard Fitzwilliams told The Sun Online the choices went “hand in glove” with the mum-to-be’s personality and history – and were the biggest nod of approval yet from the Queen after the monarch handed on two of her own patronages.The commentator said: “That is an undoubted sign of approval from Her Majesty.“It comes during a period when there have been so many rumours so it’s important to stress that this speaks very much to the Queen’s appreciation of her.”Speculation was last year re that Meghan had been involved in a row with her sister-in-law Kate Middleton, while sources claimed that she was dficult to work with.It will be a busy year for Meghan, who is expecting her first child with Prince Harry in the Spring.The couple, who married in May last year, are also expecting to move to Frogmore Cottage ahead of their babys arrival.The Grade-II listed county retreat, set in four acres of rolling Oxfordshire hills, boasts four bedrooms with one converted to a dressing room.

title: giant oarfish sighting japan tsunami panic earthquakes
story: Giant Oarfish are known as the Messengers from the Sea God’s Palace and are said by some to appear on beaches ahead of submarine earthquakes.They say the massive serpent-like fish rise to the surface and beach themselves to escape being caught up in an underwater quake.However, that also ties in with the more scientic theory that the bottom-dwellers are susceptible to movements in fault lines and act out of character before a quake.The oarfish’s reputation as a creature of doom was further enhanced after  were washed up along Japan’s northern coastline in .Months later, a massive earthquake struck off northeast Japan, triggering a tsunami that killed nearly , people and destroyed the Fukushima nuclear plant.Now news of fresh sightings of stricken giants have sparked some to fear the worst.The Giant Oarfish  is the longest of the so-called bony fishes.The longest confirmed specimen was more than  feetin .However, a more commonis around . feet .It is a deep-sea fish found between  and , meters down in all major oceans.They feed on krill, small fish, and squid.They spawn late in year and oarfish larvae can be easily found at the surface.Other comments on social media sites echoed those concerns, with one post in the -Channel site claiming increased sightings were clearly “a warning”,  reports the SCMP.Its not the first time there have been suggested links between animal behaviour and earthquakes.In fact theres a long history of reports of pets, zoo animals and wildle acting very strangely in the days or minutes before a tremor is felt by humans.In February , a .-magnitude earthquake struck Haicheng, a city of  million people located in Chinas Liaoning province.But one day earlier, city officials ordered an evacuation based in part on reports of strange animal behaviour.Hibernating snakes in the area, for example, abandoned their winter hideouts months before normal. The early evacuation of Haicheng is credited with saving thousands of human lives“The link to reports of seismic activity goes back many, many years, but there is no scientic evidence of a connection so I don’t think people need to worry.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: new 300k maggie thatcher statue to be on a 10ft platform to keep out of reach of vandals
story: The £k memorial will be erected in the Tory Prime Minister’s home town of Grantham, Lincolnshire,councillors give it the green light.But local Conservatives believe it could become a likely target for politically-motivated vandals and cops are also concerned.Lincolnshire Police warned that for the motivated far-left movement... who may be committed to public activism and who are against Mrs Thatcher the passage of time does seem to have diminished that feeling.Seventeen people have objected to the Maggie statue with just seven writing to support the idea.South Kesteven District will vote on the proposals next Tuesday.A police report to the development management committee said: In general there remains a motivated far-left movement across the UKwho may be committed to public activism.Margaret Thatcher does however maintain an element of emblematic signicance to many on the left and the passage of time does seem to have diminished that intensity of feeling.Currently, the only marking of Baroness Thatcher in the Lincolnshire town is a plaque on the corner of North Parade and Broad Street to show where she was born.Plans to erect the statue in Westminster were rejected by Westminster Council last year with a report saying it could have attracted potential vandalism and civil disorder.The report to the authority in Lincolnshire said these issues were present in this case.It said: The isive nature of Baroness Thatcher due to her political career and policy legacy and the potential for this to result in vandalism has been raised as a concern.A threat assessment has been carried out by Lincolnshire Police who consider there is a possibility any public statue of Baroness Thatcher could be a target for politically motivated vandals.Lincolnshire Polices Crime Prevention Officer has not objected to the proposal but they have recommended the statue is placed on a sufficiently high plinth and is sited in a location that benefits from good natural surveillance title: brit tourist fly larvae forehead african holiday
story: She landed in the UK with a growing lump on her head - only to discover that she actually had a load of baby flies buried into her scalp.It wasnt until about nine days after landing on home turf that she realised something was wrong, and headed to AE.Medics first said that her swollen lump was simply a bug bite, and she was sent home with a course of antibiotics.Three days later, however, the lump had grown bigger and more painful. The swelling on her forehead now extended to include more of her face and eyelids, and she experienced sharp, shooting pains in the area.So she ed to hospital, and this time, docs discovered an opening in the centre of the lump which was leaking a watery discharge.According to Dr Farah Shahi, an infectious disease specialist at York Teaching Hospital who treated the woman, the opening was actually a breathing hole for a baby fly or maggot.Doctors applied petroleum jelly to the area which essentially blocked the insects source of air - forcing it to move towards the surface of the skin.After that, they were able to remove the live maggot from the womans forehead before it was sent to the London School of Tropical Medicine for examination.The larva was identied as Lunds fly - a rare species from the rainforests in Africa.An ultrasound found that there were more baby flies in the womans forehead and she had to have surgery to remove them.These flies dont usually infect people, according to the British Medical Journal case report.So, how did it come to buried into her face The most likely explanation is that she wrapped her hair in a damp towel that was infested with maggots, Dr Shahi told Live Science.The towel had been hanging on an outdoor clothing line, and a fly couldve laid its eggs on the towel, which hatched into maggots.Theres only been one other case in the UK of such an infestation its super unusual for these flies to burrow into foreheads as they usually go for the skin on the chest, back, belly and thighs.After four days in hospital, the woman was sent home.

title: muslim school stops girls eating lunch boys finished ofsted

We have commented on reports but we havent seen a change there.This is where I talk about the isolation. We go out there. We make these tough decisions and we often take quite a lot of criticism for the stance we take but we dont always see the enforcement action we would like to see.Mr Tryl added that while Ofsted can highlight segregation in its inspection reports, laws can only be enforced by the Department for Education.He said: Our inspectors are going out and having to make some quite tricky judgements where there are those potential clashes [between laws and religious freedoms].We perhaps don’t always feel we get the support we need from the rest of Government in pushing that forward.Ofsted rated the school as inadequate in .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: venezuela sell hair jewellery flee inflation maduro vietnam

title: postman has finger torn off by a staffie as he pushes letter through door
story: Keith Bourne lost the tip of his ring finger after Emma Knells dog bit him during a routine delivery - but the dog owner tried to claim he was trespassing when the attack happened.Knell, , also told police that her dog always reacted when the post was delivered and frequently tried to grab it.Sevenoaks Magistrates Court heard yesterday that since the attack on April , an external letterbox has been put in.Keith, who lost part of his right ring finger, said: I was just posting a letter, it didnt go right through the door so I pushed it through and the dog bit my finger, thats it.I expected a guilty verdict because I couldnt see any defence for her. Shes the dog owner, shes responsible for her dog.The postie claimed that as Knell had no house insurance or pet insurance he wouldnt get any compensation out of it.He continued: Im just glad she was found guilty for some sort of justice to be done. It has been quite traumatic. I wont do that round now, but I am still a postman.At first I wanted to stay inside, but once I went out and got the confidence back, Im not too bad.Im still frightened when I see a dog but thats to be expected.Knell, of East Malling, Kent, was convicted of owning a dog dangerously out of control causing injury.Nigel Pilkington, from the CPS, said: The defendant knew how her dog reacted to the post being delivered and failed to do anything about it, which led to this attack.The defence had claimed that the postman was trespassing on the defendants property, as he had to enter through a gate.But it was our case that postmen and women have to be able to securely deliver the mail and therefore have a right to be on someones property.He continued: The law was changed precisely to protect postmen and women who enter private property.This means they do have to put their fingers through a letterbox on occasions and should be able to do so without fear of attack.Knell will be sentenced in March.

title: labour mps face hard left purge as corbyn aides plan to make them reapply for their job
story: Sources told The Sun that officials led by general secretary Jennie Formby have been asked to present formal guidance to the party’s ruling NEC policy board in March.It follows a decision from Labour’s Organisation Committee this month.The guidance will give each constituency Labour party clear rules and a timetable for re-selecting their MP ahead of a General Election.It means sitting MPs will have to re-apply and face a beauty contest to be the candidate for their seat in the next election.MPs told The Sun they fear it will trigger the long-feared “purge” by the hard-left of Labour moderates.One senior party member said: “This is the purge moderates have been worrying about ever since Jeremy became leader.“Why would you want to have a contest for sitting MPs  It’s beyond belief.”No sitting Labour MPs faced a re-selection ahead of the  Election.The Labour leadership had promised that any shake-up would be held off until the Government’s boundary review – which Theresa May shelved in September.Last year party members backed proposals to lowered the threshold for a re-selection ballot to just  per cent of local branches.

title: mysterious wreck in sea off papua new guinea could be amelia earharts plane researchers claim
story: The legendary pilots disappearance in  - during a flight to Howland Island in the Pacic  - is a mystery that continues to intrigue people to this day.Now there is renewed hope the baffling riddle of the deep may finally have been solved - more than  years later.William Snavely, director of Project Blue Angel , said: “Were still exploring to try to find out whose plane it is. We dont want to jump ahead and assume that its Amelia’s.“But everything that were seeing so far would tend to make us think it could be.”Divers first studied the wreckage in August and discovered several characteristics of Earharts plane including what could be light lens from the plane.Speaking to Live Science, Mr Snavely said: “Its obviously glass that appears to be old and covered signicantly with barnacles.“It has a rough shape and diameter that appears to be relatively consistent with lights that were on the plane back in the s for Lockheed.But we dont know for sureits a Lockheed light. Thats what were getting checked right now.The team is now raising cash on GoFundMe in the hopes of completing more es.Earhart set many early aviation records at a time when there were hardly any female pilots.She was an accomplished flyer who in  became the first woman to make a solo flight across the Atlantic.Her adventures brought her global fame before her disappearance at the age of .The good looking aviatrix was an A-list celeb of her era which saw her dubbed “Lady Lindy” in a nod to the other famous aviator Charles Lindbergh.The famed pilot, who was the first female aviator to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean, went missing during an attempt to make a circumnavigational flight around the globe.The message said she could not find the island and her Lockheed Electra L-E was nearly out fuel. Then silence.Amelia was declared dead two years later, and it has always been assumed she died in the smash, with her remains being lost to the deep waters.Various theories then surfaced.One was the Japanese held her prisoner as a suspected spy after she crash landed in the Marshall Islands. Some believe she had really been on a secret reconnaissance mission and that after the war she ed to the USA where she lived under an assumed identity.If confirmed as Earharts wreckage, the discovery would cast doubt on claims last year that her skeleton had been found on another island, Nikumaroro.Richard Jantz, an emeritus anthropology professor at the University of Tennessee, concluded the bones are almost certainly Earhart’s after measurements.

title: frost quake midwest polar vortex explosion frozen earth
story: Locals in the states of Ohio and Pennsylvania say the roaring frost quakes, also known as cryoseisms, have been consistently booming from the ground.Michelle Tebbetts, a resident of Dillburg, Pennsylvania, told WHP-TV: It sounded like a big piece of furniture fell over.Her husband Steven added: These frost quakes, they sound more like a boom or a bang and then we get a little shake in the house.The weather got so freezing in Chicago that train tracks have been set on fire to keep the steel from freezing so that commuter trains can keep running.Metra Commuter Rail spokeswoman, Mel Riele, told Chicago Tribune: Basically, what the fires are, theyre gas powered switch heaters and essentially youre looking at a giant gas grill.The polar vortex, dragging in extreme arctic temperatures, has led to emergency measures in Minnesota, Iowa, Illinois, Wisconsin and Michigan.Among the worst affected cities is Chicago - where daytime highs reached only a bitter -C- leading to frozen pipes, roads turning to ice blocks and the threat of frostbite in just minutes.NBC Storm Team  meteorologist Andy Avalos warned those in Chicago: “If you don’t have to go outside today, don’t.He added: Wind chill values are -F to -F which could lead to frostbite and hypothermia in just a matter of minutes to any exposed skin.The lowest wind chill recorded was a teeth-chattering -Cat Thief River Falls, Minnesota, on Tuesday evening, according to AccuWeather.More than , flights were cancelled on Wednesday due to freak snowsqualls - with more travel chaos at US airports expected on Thursday.In Iowa, the body of -year-old student Gerald Belz was found behind an academic hall in Iowa City just before am on Wednesday by campus police.Belzs family told KCRG that doctors did not find alcohol in his system - title: brexit remainers facebook adverts peoples vote second referendum
story: Millions of Brits have seen adverts pushed out by the Peoples Vote campaign in a last-ditch attempt to try and keep us in the EU.Most of the adverts feature Theresa Mays face on, and urge Brits to write to their MP now to demand a second Brexit vote to try and overturn the referendum result.During January alone the campaign have put out  adverts, at an estimated total cost of between £, and £,, figures from Storyful social intelligence news agency show.At least three million people have seen the campaigns adverts, but it could be as high as EIGHT million.Slogans read: Our country is in crisis and no more excuses with a nudge to tell their MP to back a second isive vote, or sign a petition.And after this weeks Brexit votes they targeted MPs who voted for the deal, saying they opted to make the country poorer.Many people are being targeted right down to their inidual regions too.Some of the ads were seen by more than one million people in a matter of days - which would have cost up to £, to run.On the th and th - the run up to the crunch Brexit vote which Mrs May lost by  votes - a whopping  ads were placed by the Peoples Vote Campaign.Other Remain groups such as Best for Britain also pumped out paid-for messages, but far fewer.Theresa May has repeatedly said she wont hold another Brexit vote on EU membership, saying its her duty to deliver on the result of the first vote.Pro-Brexit group Britains Future have pumped out hundreds of adverts too to try and counter the flood of Remainer ads.Leave Means Leave only put out nine paid ads on Facebook in the past month - and most were advertising an event.We are the % have put out over  adverts in the same time, pushing us to leave on World Trade Organisation terms, and encouraging MPs who voted against Brexit to be deselected.Tory MP David Davies told The Sun Online: This just shows Remainers will do anything they can to keep us in the EU - including spending thousands of pounds on adverts to try and sway the public.We already had a Peoples Vote in  - and the people voted to Leave.This week Remainers have been scrambling to rescue the campaign for a second Brexit vote after MPs blocked a bid to delay our exit date.After the Commons showdown campaigners have admitted that a second vote is in the last chance saloon.And the news came as Facebook earlier this week restricted the ability of political transparency campaigners to monitor adverts on the social media network.Monitoring tools which are used to keep track of adverts have stalled after the site changed their codes.Earlier this week ex-deputy PM Nick Clegg revealed that the site would begin vetting political advertisers in Europe and display who pays for them, from March.All advertisers will have to register in order to put out ads in future - and users will be able to see how many people also saw them.A spokesperson for the People’s Vote campaign said: “The People’s Vote campaign is supported by the generous donations of tens of thousands of people who support giving the final say on Brexit back to the public.Like many campaign groups we use Facebook to directly reach millions of people in the UK, both through users sharing our videos and stories and also with paid advertising.All People’s Vote adverts are clearly marked as coming from us and we are proud to be a part of a growing movement of people across the country, whether they voted Leave or Remain, who now realise the only way forward on Brexit will be a People’s Vote.”

title: brexit latest cabinet remainer block no deal brussels
story: Amber Rudd and Greg Clark warned last night they WILL stop us leaving with nothing on March .It comes after MPs rejected a plan earlier this week from Labours Yvette Cooper to delay Brexitwe were heading for a No Deal.Business Secretary Greg Clark said last night: Ive always been very clear. I think to leave in a disorderly way on the  March would be very bad for everyone in the economy.I will do everything that I can to make sure that doesnt happen.That is the purpose of having a position of influence in government, to be able to do that.Amber Rudd backed up his comments with a supportive tweet last night, adding Well said.Their warnings come as this morning Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt hinted that Brexit could have to be delayeda deal isnt done soon.But Mr Clark actually went even further on ITVs Peston show last night, hinting that he wants the PM to reach out to Labour and offer a customs union with the bloc to win over the Opposition.He said that because of the close result of the referendum, politicians needed to make sure the deal was getting more support than just winning by a vote or two.And he went on: Not only do I think it is necessary for people to come together across partisan lines, but actually I thinkwe are to properly move forward I don’t think we should aim for this deal to pass by a majority of one or two …I would like to see a substantial majority for a deal.Yesterday Mrs May held talks with Jeremy Corbyn where the pair discussed a customs union, which the Labour boss wants.But the discussions soon descended into chaos after he accused her of running down the clock and she denied going soft on the EU.On Tuesday night MPs opted not to back a Remainer plan to put off our EU exit by up to a year to avoid us leaving with nothing.But MPs did vote to back a separate amendment saying Britain shouldnt leave with nothing, indicating it would be incredibly dficult for the PM to push that plan through.Shes refused to take the option off the table because it would take the pressure off Brussels to give us a good deal that we want.The PM saw off a possible rebellion on the Cooper plan this week when she promised ministers that they could have another say on stopping No Deal later on.Other Cabinet ministers have urged her to plan and get ready for us to leave with nothing - with is looking more and more likely as the clock ticks down to exit day in March.Meanwhile, earlier today the Institute for Government said today that the UK is unprepared for leaving without an agreement.IFG director Bronwen Maddox told the BBC: The UK is not ready for no-deal.

title: eurocrat martin selmayr no deal brexit merkel
story: Martin Selmayr, said by some to be the power behind the EU throne, insisted Europe shouldnt be worried by No Deal.His comments came as he urged European leaders to take a tough line on Britain, according to Politico.Mr Selmayr, right-hand man to European Commission boss Jean-Claude Juncker, told diplomats they shouldnt strike mini deals with the UK.It came as the EU fights to keep a united line against Theresa Mays request to rewrite the existing Brexit deal.The PM is lobbying Brussels to ditch the Irish backstop after MPs agreed to back the withdrawal agreement as long as the backstop is cut out.Angela Merkel has told allies she will go to the edge of the precipice with Mrs May rather than folding in the near future.The German leader added that Britain should look into the abyss before a deal is done at five to midnight.And Austrian foreign minister Karin Kneissl claimed No Deal is now the most likely outcome.She told the BBC: Its very dficult to imagine that there can be a tremendous breakthrough - a magic solution - in the next few days.Senior Tory Oliver Letwin, who has backed the PMs deal, said the chances of Britain crashing out are enormously high.The MoDs top civil servant told top brass they should devote their efforts to preparing Britain to leave the EU without a deal.It comes as the military prepares to hold a series of war games designed to simulate the worst-case scenarios which some fear could result from No Deal.According to Sky News, MoD permanent secretary Stephen Lovegrove wrote: As a department, we have already made signicant progress with our no-deal preparations.This includes both our internal planning to mitigate the impacts on defence itself as well as the wider support we have provided to the cross-government effort.However, moving into the New Year we will not only have to continue this hard work but treat it as our highest priority.He warned that other military work could be scrapped to free up resources.He added: I think the great likelihood is that is where we will end up, as things currently stand.I think there’s almost no chance at all of her coming back with anything she can sell to the Conservative Party’s ERG group.And a new poll found  per cent of voters saying No Deal is the most likely Brexit outcome - more than any other scenario.

title: no deal brexit schools teacher checks
story: Schools would lose access to an international database which flags banned teachers, at the end of March.Teachers who are slapped with sanctions or restrictions on teaching in their home countries might not be flagged up after we go.That would leave schools to make their own checks when they hire staff from the EU - rather than using a Government scheme as they do now.Officials revealed today that they will update schools shortly on keeping children safe guidance.Sources confirmed to The Sun that EU citizens would face similar checks to those from outside the bloc in a No Deal situation.And hiring more teachers after a No Deal could be even harder as their qualications might not be recognised, officials warned.The Department also said that schools could have to rip up their menus because of fears they wont be able to get enough access to enough fresh food.The new guidance comes exactly two months before Britain is set to leave the EU, revealing the poor state of No Deal planning in Whitehall.A Cabinet source said: This is the sort of thing that shouldnt be affected by Brexit at all - but it would be a problem under No Deal.Education Select Committee boss Robert Halfon told The Sun he was incredibly alarmed at the latest warnings from the Government.He said today: It is vital that the Department for Education reassures teachers and parents as soon as possible that safeguarding measures will be in place for teachers from Europe should there be No Deal, and that food quality standards will be maintained.And Best for Britain supporter and Lib Dem education spokesperson Layla Moran blasted: This government is in chaos - with just two months to go until the legal deadline, only now are they issuing schools with No Deal guidance.It is just staggering that they haven’t even sorted out how we’ll check the records of teachers from the EEA coming to work in Britain - a vital system which helps to keep our kids safe in school. This couldn’t be further from taking back control - the government need to be put into special measures.The note also revealed that the there could be additional checks at Britains borderswe left without a deal in March, which could have a knock on to kids school meals.Unhealthier frozen food such as chicken nuggets and turkey twizzlers could be back on the menusBritain cant get access to healthier imports in the event of delays.Officials said that schools have signicant flexibilities within the school food standards in a huge hint that menus would have to be ripped up and changed.Teachers should also think about taking kids on school holidays to Europe too, it said.The news comes just days after ministers revealed plans to give teachers cash incentives to help them stay in their classroom jobs.Some secondary school teachers in their third and fth years in the classroom could get an extra £, on top of their current bursaries to try and tackle the crisis in recruitment and retention of staff.Teacher targets for new starters are already down by  per cent.And more tired, stressed and burnt out employees are leaving their careers too, making the situation worse.

title: no deal brexit channel ports open
story: Vincent Pourquery de Boisserin said building works on new customs posts are underway and recruitment of  new staff has now been sped up.He declared: “It’s a complete change of model. My mandate is to make sure we are ready to face the most constraining situation.”Mr de Boisserin said ports were stepping up their efforts even further after warnings Tuesday’s votes in the Commons have made no deal more likely.Around  per cent of all goods and people moving between Britain and the EU go through the French harbours and the Channel Tunnel.Port authorities are hiring  extra customs staff who will initially work out of prefab buildings to cope with with increased checks.This week the president of the Calais region, Xavier Bertrand, issued a call to politicians for common sense to minimise disruptionthere’s No Deal.He said: “We mustn’t let the legal aspect become the enemy of the economics. It’s a test of pragmatism.”The remarks came as Eurostar insisted it too “will be ready as soon as March ” to carry on services as usual evenBritain leaves without a deal.A spokesman for the company said: “Eurotunnel has been actively preparing for all possibilities for the last two years, including the worst-case scenario.”

title: leavers remainers together uk flourish brexit
story: We all want certainty that we will be leaving the EU on th March.  That would enable us all to plan for le beyond Brexit and lead to a period of political calm.The Government’s deal has been rejected by Parliament.  Therefore, leavers and remainers need to come together to develop a new plan so that we can deliver the referendum result and ensure that we flourish outside the EU.This is exactly what we have tried to do with the help of Kit Malthouse. Nicky Morgan, Robert Buckland and Stephen Hammond were on dferent sides to me and Steve Baker during the referendum.  But we have decided to put our dferences aside and unite to publish a new proposal on how we should leave the EU.Leavers rejected the Government’s EU deal because the backstop would have stopped us from agreeing trade deals. So, we have suggested replacing the backstop with a new protocol that solves the concerns people have about the Irish border and which protects the Union of the United Kingdom.Remainers want a guaranteed Implementation Period – a period which allows us all to adjust to le beyond the EU.  Our plan offers a smooth transition with an additional year of the Implementation Period, making it last until no later than the end of December .Parliament, our country and the  member states of the EU are united in wanting a deal and this proposal can pass through Parliament and restore Government unity, purpose and direction.If the EU ignores this consensus, we have proposed a Plan B – a “triple safety net” to protect us.  It includes cooperation on security, a guarantee by the UK of zero tarfs, no quantitative restrictions and no new trading barriers, along with a generous offer to pay our financial contributions infor an Implementation Period.These proposals would allow everyone to prepare fully for the UK leaving the EU and gives us the space to have proper trade talks so that we can develop a close trading relationship  – which, after all, is what Brexit was supposed to be about.Millions of people voted to leave the EU so that we could become an outward- looking, strong, free-trading nation.They also wanted us to maintain the closest of friendships with our allies on the continent, to continue to trade closely with our European counterparts and to let EU citizens - who have become our friends and neighbours and made the UK their home - feel welcome here.We can still be proud of our shared European heritage after leaving the EU but we must do this as an independent nation.This plan gives us a way of doing this and we invite everyone across the House of Commons and the country to support us as we forge a deal that brings the whole country together.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsTories wont dodge blame for ending free TV licences for over-sShadow minister Steve Reed urged Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright to ditch the rule for those living aloneShareCommentsByMirror :,  JAN NewsCulture Secretary Jeremy Wright was urged to take into account the problem of loneliness "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tories will not get away with shting blame for cutting over-s’, free TV licences, MPs were told. Grilling Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright, Shadow Minister Steve Reed told a meeting: “He’s not going to get away with devolving the blame for his cuts. “More than two million over--year-olds live alone and the Campaign to End Loneliness reports four in  say television is their main source of company.”   As Chancellor in  George Osborne gave the BBC responsibility for funding the benefit from . But the Conservatives pledged at the  snap election to preserve the perk for theof this Parliament, due to run until . The BBC has begun a consultation which could curb free licences or raise the age threshold. The Mirror is campaigning to save the perk. title: unilever stockpiling magnum ice creams
story: NewsUnilever is stockpiling Magnum ice creams in case of no-deal BrexitThe worlds largest ice cream seller makes British favourites in Italy and GermanyShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsBJHF Ice cream on a stick, a bite taken. Image shot . Exact date unknown."Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Unilever is stockpiling ice creams in Britain to guard against potential supply disruptions in the event of a no-deal Brexit .The Anglo-Dutch consumer giant, which is the worlds largest ice cream seller, makes British favourites likeMagnumbars and Ben and Jerrys in Italy and Germany. It is building up a few weeks of extra stock in Britain in case of any border delays. Likewise, several of its European deodorants, including Axe, Dove and Rexona are made in Britain and transported to the continent. A few weeks of extra inventory is one of the important steps we are taking to make sure that we minimise any disruption to our customers and consumers, said Alan Jope, Unilevers new chief executive.   He said weeks of inventory, not months and not days was the right amount for consumer packaged goods. One of the lessons we learn over and over again is when you do build inventory, it very often ends up being not exactly the right mix of products. With Britain at risk of leaving the European Union without a deal, Unilever is the latest consumer and retail firm to take such measures to keep imports and exports smooth. Unilever makes other British staples, such as Marmite spread, in Britain. Unilever is also increasing stocks of raw materials such as aluminium cans and cardboard. Such logistical costs are among those the Anglo-Dutch company has incurred this year to prepare for Brexit. The others are artwork changes to labels to prepare for dferent regulations and the hiring of customs experts. In very round numbers these are roughly equal and not material to total Unilever at the moment, Jope said.

title: bbc finalists 20th century greatest
story: NewsBBC finalists for th century greatest person are all men - where are the women Historians claim women have been unfairly airbrushed from the history books despite playing just as much a part in shaping our worldShareCommentsByMatt Roper:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsMarie Curie, who won the Nobel prize twice, didnt make the list "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHistory was made by men - or at least that what the BBC ’s Icons audience might have us believe. When viewers were asked to vote for the most iconic human beings of the th century, only male figures made the final seven. Among them were deserving contenders such as Nelson Mandela , Pablo Picasso and ‘father of computing’ Alan Turing. But many - just as worthy - women didn’t get a look in, such as Nobel prize winner Marie Curie, suffragette leader Emmeline Pankhurst and Hollywood legend Marilyn Monroe. Down the centuries women have played a central part in shaping the world, and the th century had more impressive women than ever - Rosa Parks, Florence Nightingale, Mother Teresa and Queen Elizabeth II, to name just a few.   So why, when presented with both the male and female history-makers, did viewers of the BBC show cast their votes for the men, not the women  A BBC spokesperson would only point out that the programme “gave the public their say on who should be crowned the greatest person of the th Century”. They added that three episodes were hosted by women and next Tuesdays final will have a female co-host. The poll is set to reignite the debate about why the writing and retelling of history is still skewered in favour of men, despite there being so many inspirational women. Incredibly, while women make up  per cent of the world’s population, they only occupy around . per cent of recorded history.   Historian Dr Bettany Hughes believes women have traditionally been “written out of history” - meaning that most people haven’t heard the stories of the female leaders, pioneers and trend-setters who have shaped our world. She said: “There are brilliantly feisty women from history who have made an impact, and whose stories need to be told. For historians it’s our job to fill in the gaps in history. “We need to actively look for women’s stories, and put them back into the historical narrative, there are so many women that should be household names but just aren’t.  “I don’t think there are malign forces at work here, it’s just a practical issue. Physically the stories of women have been written out of history, rather than written in.” Her theory was backed up by a survey for Women’s History Month in March , in which  per cent of respondents said they thought women hadn’t impacted history as much as men. June Purvis, professor of women and gender history at Portsmouth University, said history has always been written by men, about men. Its about mens activities, in politics, in war. Its led to the traditional view of history, that it was men who made it. It wasnt until the s that womens part in history began to be acknowledged. A lot of us now spend time trying to find women in the past and put them back into history to try to balance it out. But a lot still needs to be done, in schools, in higher education, and in popular history magazines who rarely feature women in their pages. Last year, Tess Davidson, a history finalist at King’s College, Cambridge, claimed that historical women were being sidelined at university history courses too, including Cambridge, where she claimed she was told incorporating women historical figures would be seen as too “feminist” for the more traditional academics. She said: During my studies Ive encountered the two extremes: the look of fear in a male historians eyes when you mention gender, and the tokenistic attempts at this kind of history, purely as a tick-box approach to political-correctness. To illustrate how women’s stories are often absent from school history lessons, she wrote: “As a curious project, I asked several of my friends to list off the top of their heads three famous women they knew from history. “I got the inevitable Thatcher reference, Elizabeth I, Cleopatra, as well as a few throw-backs to A-Level courses.  “But in the main, these were larger than le caricatures, figures referenced within popular culture as much as historical studies. “When pushed to suggest names of lesser known women, I was greeted with silence. “While by no means an exhaustive survey, it provides a brief insight nonetheless into the extent to which a separation of men and women has been incorporated into the teaching of history in schools.” In fact, women have often played more important roles than men in some of the key moments of history. Queen Victoria, for instance, oversaw the abolition of slavery around the world, brought in voting and labour reforms, and led Britain towards an era of unprecedented wealth and power with the industrial revolution and the expanding British empire. Among many little-known ancient warrior queens is Boudicca, who led a first century revolt against the Roman colonisation of Britain around BC, while her army of , sacked Colchester and then London.  AndEleanor of Aquitaine,Queen consort of France and England,was one of the most powerful and wealthy women in western Europe during the High Middle Ages. She led armies to victory in key battles several times in her le. Bettany Hughes says that to understand the problem of why women are underrepresented in the history books, you need to go back to pre-history, when women were actually more prominent than men. She added: “If you look at all the figurines made between about , BC, until around , BC – a period which really sees the flourishing of the modern mind - at that time around  per cent of all these figurines are of women. “So women are very present in the archaeological record, but then start to disappear once pre-history turns into history.” She explains that as civilisations wanted to expand, they began to value the military clout and muscle power of men more than the intellect and creativity of women. The retelling of history, then, started to focus on male figures and their successes.  Women, meanwhile, became mere footnotes in history - unless they could be portrayed as sexual seductresses. Bettany said: A lot of the women that we think of, like Cleopatra and Helen of Troy, one of the reasons their stories have lasted is that they are portrayed as highly sexualised. Cleopatra was a poet and a philosopher, she was incredible good at maths, she wasnt much of a looker. But when we think of her, we think: big breasted seductress in milk. Often, even when women have made their mark and they are remembered by history, we are offered a fantasy version of their lives. But she says there is still time to put things right and make sure history’s exceptional women receive the recognition they deserve.  She added: “Whenever I feel sad about how systematically women vanished from history, I take the long view, and say, there has been a problem here for at least , years, so it’s no surprise that we have some catching up to do. “But that in itself is quite empowering, because we know what we are up against. “This is an issue that has very deep roots, and we can see how and why that plays out, and therefore what we can do to start to change things. “What we need to do is make sure that collectively we are known as the generation that opened rather than closed minds, and who opened these stories up, and put them back onto the page and into our collective memory.” Who are the seven male finalists Nelson Mandela   Born in , Nelson Mandela was arrested in  and sentenced to le in prison on Rodden Island. He spent a huge amount of time in solitary confinement before he was finally released in  after massive global presure. Mandela was elected South Africas first free elections in  and instead of responding to the treatment of black people in the country, responded with the idea of the Rainbow Nation. His actions of governing for the while country and not just a section are credited with preventing South Africa crumbling into civil war. He died in  and his methods of forgiveness over revenge have been used as a model for other countries. Ernest Shackleton Shackleton was born in Kilkea, Ireland in . He was hailed a hero when, on an expedition to the South Pole, he and his crew got stranded in Antarctica. He refused to give up hope and sailed across almost frozen seas, before climbing across an island to reach help. Every, single member of his crew made it home alive. Alan Turing   Turing is the man widely credited with turning the tide of World War Two. he built a code cracking machine to speed up the time it took to decipher messages. Turing also invented the first computer. His legacy has also shaped attitudes in Britain. Turing was openly gay when homosexuality was illegal. He was arrested and had to chose between prison or chemical castration and opted for the latter. He was posthumously pardoned in . David Bowie  One of the most cutting edge perfromers throughout his career, Bowie was known for his multiple personas. He passed away in January  - but not before he released a final album inspired by his impending death. Dr Martin Luther King  Dr King as a civil rights leader credited with changing the landscape of America. Martin Luther King used Gandhis method of non-violent resistance and following Rosa Parks refusal to give up a seat on a segrgated bus he organised a -month boycott of buses. His peaceful protests resulted in a huge rally of , people in Washington. Dr King as shot dead  by a far-right gunman in Memphis. Muhammad Ali  The world wept when Muhammed Ali passed away in . Often described as the greatest boxer who ever live, something he even described himself as. Ali was never afraid to speak his mind and loudly proclaimed his political views. He was banned from boxing and even threatened with prison. Ali was diagnosed with Parkinsons Disease but continued his work outside the ring, even helping secure the freedom of  US hostages from Iraq after the  Gulf War. Pablo Picasso   The Spanish artists work spans a huge number of styles and genres. His abstract work influenced a whole generation of artists. And his used his paintings to push his political beliefs - painting Guernica when Spain was in the middle of a bloody civil war. And the women who could have made the final list Marie Curie  As a woman, Marie Curie was forced to study in secret. Despite this she was one of just three women to win the Nobel Prize for physics. Curie was the first person to coin the term radioactivity after realising certain elements gave off rays. Even though she suffered personal tragedy with the death of her husband she continued her research and even bought portable X-ray machines to treat troops on the frontline in World War One. Emmeline Pankhurst  A fierce campaigner for womens rights and votes in Britain. She funded the deeds not words movement and the women became known as suffragettes. And Pankhurst led from the front, even spending time in prison. When the First World War broke out, she called on women to stop the violence and take up the tools of the men. In  her victory was secured and women over  were given the vote. Marilyn Monroe  She was the original blonde bombshell and was a hugely successful entertainer right up until her untimely death in . Even though Marilyn played up to her dumb blonde on screen persona, she smashed the studio system by setting up her own production company and even owned the rights to her own images. Margaret Thatcher  Britains first female Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher was born in Grantham in . She was nick named the Iron Lady after her famous quote the ladys not for turning. Her firm beliefe in the free market and her policies became known as Thatcherism. Margaret Thatcher died in . Virginia Woolf  An author who completely rewrote the rule book on writing. Her hugely influential works are still widely read today and she battled severe mood swings all her le. Woolf fiercely supported other artists and set up Hogarth Press from her Richmond home. She published works by TS Elliot, EM Forster and Gertrude Stein. Woolf drowned herself by walking into a river with her pockets full of stones in . Billie Jean King  She is widely recognised as revolutionising the womens game. King was a Grand Slam winning player and was key in organising a womens tour in . She threatened to boycott the US Open as part of her campaign for equal pay and thrashed Bobby Riggs in te battle of the sexes.

title: britains wastelands clean up tackles
story: NewsBritains wastelands: Clean-up tackles plastic refuse that is threat to wildleParks and waterways across Britain have become polluted with mounds of rubbish that are more than just an eyesoreShareCommentsByNada Farhoud:,  JAN NewsA brilliant team of volunteers tackles the trash at Hamadryad Park in Cardf "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailUgly plastic waste dumped on a nature reserve clogs the wetlands where wildle is supposed to flourish. Parks and waterways across the UK have become polluted with mounds of rubbish which are more than just an eyesore. So congratulations are due to a brilliant team of volunteers who tackled the trash at shyHamadryad Park in Cardf. They filled  rubbish bags in a big clean-up at the nature reserve, which is much loved by bird-watchers.  They also collected discarded traffic cones, road barriers, cable drums and a host of other items dumped at the site that were too big to bag. Across the channel in Bristol, mute swans were pictured foraging among litter floating on the river Avon. And fed-up residents of the Leeds South Bank development on the Aire told the Mirror about a floating “plasberg” there last week. Volunteers took to the water in canoes to help clear it as others cleaned from the path, collecting  bags of waste from only a -metre stretch.  Most of it was plastic food and drink containers and polystyrene packaging. The Mirror, with environment charity Hubbub, is offering a visit from a Plastic Fishing boat, made from recycled plastic waste, to communities wanting to clear waterways. Hubbub chief Trewin Restorick said: “It is incredibly heartening to see the desire to tackle the problem.” Four groups can win a visit and one will be chosen to keep the boat. For a chance to win, go to hubbub.org.uk by February .

The holidaymakers - thought to be from Liverpool - were issued a deportation notice earlier this month after being accused of a string of offences. After they made headlines across the world for their unruly behaviour, pensioner Heidrun Leonard from Auckland came forward saying she recognised some of them as builders who allegedly scammed her out of thousands. She claims three men knocked on her door saying they had spotted a leak that needed fixing - charging her - around pound,. The men allegedly said they would fix tiles on her roof and install two dehumidiers in her home, but needed the money upfront.   Heidrun wrote them a cheque which they allegedly cashed at the bank, before ing the next day to cut a whole in her ceiling. The men then allegedly fled after a neighbour arrived and began asking questions.On January , disturbing footage emerged on social media of tourists dumping rubbish and empty alcohol bottles on Takapuna Beach.A boy from the group - thought to be just eight-years-old allegedly threatened to knock the brains out of a local who challenged them. The Mayor of Auckland labelled them worse than pigs and called them a**holes.A video of the group was widely shared on Facebook captured by local Krista Curnow.  Posting on Facebook, she said: We approached the family to ask themthey can please not leave without picking up their rubbish, their response was basicallywe have a problem then we can pick it up and that thats what the council is for. She claimed four or five ladies had stood around her, saying they were going to hit her.But the group hit back in an interview with the Herald , and family member David Johnson said rubbish left behind the group was not the end of the world.  It is also alleged that the family refused to pay a bill from Backyard Bar and Restaurant after claiming there were ants in their food and threatened staff and left without paying at Artwok eatery in Takapuna.On January , a petition was launched on Change.org to get rid of the group and teach them a lesson, news.au reports.They were deported from the country just a few days ago, arriving atHeathrow Airport in west London where they allegedly threatened photographers and reporters.

title: brutal stepdad made kids lives
story: NewsBrutal stepdad made kids lives hell before brutally killing their mumEXCLUSIVE: Kirstie Hemming tells how her stepdad Paul mentally abused her and her siblings - including making them stand in the naughty corner for  hoursShareCommentsBySally Beck:,  JAN NewsSalesman Hemming, , brutally killed mum Natalie Hemming in the sitting room of their Milton Keynes home while her children slept upstairs "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailStanding stock still in the “naughty corner”, Kirstie knew she could not move. She did not dare to sit down even for a few minutes. Instead the terried schoolgirl stared at the wall, knowing her stepdad Paul Hemming could come back at any moment to check she was still there. So from pm until am, on a school night, she stood and waited. The crime she was being punshyshyished for  A forgotten piece of fruit. Kirstie says: “He found an apple in my school bag that had gone soft and he was really angry. He made me scrub out the bag and I had to stand in the naughty corner from pm until am –  hours. “He went to bed, but kept checking I was still standing.”   It is just one example of the abuse Kirstie, now , and her two siblings endured at the hands of the salesman before he killed their mum in the sitting room as they slept upstairs. Natalie Hemming was beaten and dumped in woods in . The investigation into the -year-old’s death was shown in heartbreaking detail in the documentary Catching a Killer. Kirstie is telling her story in a moving follow-up, Behind Closed Doors: Through the Eyes of the Child on BBC. For  years up to her murder, Natalie endured horrendous physical and emotional abuse, bullied by a man now described as a Jekyll and Hyde character. Kirstie and the two children Natalie had with Hemming – a son, eight, and daughter, six, who cannot be named – saw everything. They also bore the brunt of Hemming’s anger.   Until Natalie went missing Kirstie suffered in silence, like the one-in-five children in England and Wales who witness and experience domestic abuse. “I thought it was normal,” she says. “There were naughty corners all over the house I had to stand inI did something wrong. Anything could set him off.” Talking for the first time about her stepfather, jailed for le, Kirstie continues: “If I hadn’t hung my clothes up properly, orI got a bad grade at school... he got angry on a daily basis, mostlythings were untidy. “I wasn’t allowed out to play with friends or to bring them home. I was sent to bed without food for things like forgetting a piece of homework.” The only person who really knew the extent of her suffering was her mum, and she was powerless to help. “Mum would try and sneak food to me, but she wasn’t always able to. If she got found out, Paul would go mad.  “I once told a teacher that Daddy wasn’t being very nice. She did the right thing and told the head. It was reported to social services but they called Mum, who said everything was fine. “The file was closed the same day.” The abuse started in  after Natalie, then a -year-old single mum, moved in with Hemming,  years older. Natalie’s relationship with Kirstie’s dad Matthew, a naval officer, had broken down and she had postnatal depression. Things quickly deteriorated. Kirstie recalls: “When I was about four I got stuck in between Mum and Paul, who were shouting at each other. I was shyterried and went to my bedroom. “After that, when the fighting started, I’d go to my room and play with my toys. I had a rabbit called Thumper, I’d act out what was happenshyshying with him.” The incidents were never talked about as the family were so terried. Kirstie tells her story in the documentary along with three other victims of abusive and controlling fathers.To the outshy-side world, Hemming was a charmer attheir home inMilton Keynes,he was a monster. He was moody, sullen, controlled Natalie’s money and constantly checked up on her. When she wanted a job, Hemming told her he would pay her to stay home. Natalie’s sister Joanne Beverley, , says: “Natalie always said Paul had two faces – the face she and the children lived with and the face everyone  saw. “Natalie hinted that things were off, saying he was very obsessive. “Then she would defend him, saying he’d got obsessive compulsive disorder but was getting help for it. “She never told me too much as she knew I’d insist she left.” Jo lives in Wakefield, West Yorks, with her husband Stephen, , and four children, Lauren, , Morgan, , Charlie, five, and Isabelle, three. After the murder, she took in Kirstie and her half-sister. Jo’s other sister Kerry Hammond, , who has two sons, took in Natalie’s little boy. Jo, Kerry and their brothers Stephen, , and Sean, , all wish they could have done more to help Natalie. Jo says: “Once, we nearly managed to get her away from him. But Paul kept turning up, he wore her down in the end and she decided to go home.” Finally, Natalie planned to leave him after finding love with a colleague at the Mercedes dealership she worked at. Hemming, then , found out.  On May , , he beat Natalie to death, wrapped her body in a blanket, shoved her into his car boot and dumped her naked body in woodlands in shyChandlers Cross, Herts. Their son, then six, had heard the murder. He told police: “I heard a noise. I looked downstairs and peeked through the little door. Mum was lying down on the floor.” The children were traumatised. Jo says: “Kirstie was completely shut down when she came to live with me, she was almost robotic. Her sister didn’t speak for two months. She’s only just found the confidence to speak outside the home. “The day we heard Natalie’s body had been found, three weeks after she went missing, I told [the children]. “Kirstie sat showing no emotion. She was like a rabbit caught in the headlights. She only started talking about it after Hemming was sentenced.” Kirstie vividly recalls the last time she saw Natalie. “Mum was cuddled up on the sofa with a blanket on the Sunday night and I gave her a kiss.” When Natalie was not downstairs on Monday morning, Hemming lied to Kirstie and said that her mum was out with friends. After Natalie’s body was found, his web of lies began to unravel. He was charged with her murder and sentenced to a minimum of  years’ jail.  Though Kirstie says: “I was too frightened to talk. I didn’t even want to tell the police what I knew in case they told Paul. I knew he’d be really angry.” Jo has nurtured both girls back to good health. Kirstie has started her GCSEs and joined the Sea Cadets. She thinks she will join the Navy, like her mum did before having her, and her real dad is back in her le. She also wants to help other shyyoungsters suffering domestic violence. In a school of , children, statistics say  will experience it. Kirstie says: “I’m a patron of Operation Encompass, which supports children suffering abuse. If police are called to a house for domshyshyestic violence, they have to let the school know. Teachers can then talk to the children and ask themthey’re OK. “It’s really hard to go up to a teacher and tell them what’s happening, butsomeone comes to you it’s much easier to speak out.” Remembering her mum, she adds: “Mum loved sparkly shoes. We asked everyone to wear party shoes to her funeral. Mum was bubbly and fun.” Jo says: “Natalie was a great mum and a strong character. If domestic violence can happen to her, it can to anyone.” Behind Closed Doors: Through the Eyes of the Child, BBC at pm on Wednesday, February .

title: call over 75s given statins
story: NewsCall for over-s to be given statins to help stop heart attacksThe move would save up to , lives a year and stop thousands more suffering disabilities, say expertsShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent:,  JAN NewsThe researchers estimated around . million over-s should take the tablets "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailScientists say all those aged over  should be offered statins to help prevent heart attacks and strokes. It would save up to , lives a year and stop thousands more suffering disabilities as a result of the medical emergencies, experts believe. The researchers estimated around . million over-s take the tablets and that the remaining . million should be prescribed them too, eventhey have healthy levels of cholesterol. Statins are shown to lower “bad” cholesterol, the type that can cause heart attacks and strokes.  Author of the study Prof Colin Baigent, of Oxford University, said ageism is one of the reasons why some older people are not offered the pills. He added: “The idea is the person is elderly so they are going to have many other things happen to them, so why bother ” The review in the Lancet, the biggest of its type, looked at  global clinical trials covering , people, , who were over-. Statins have previously been linked to problems such as muscle damage. Prof Baigent said: “There are some hazards but these are massively outweighed by the benefits.” A healthy diet and increased exercise can be more effective than statins.

story: NewsGraduate turns down job after boss reminds her of abusive ex in humiliating interviewThe CEO of Web Applications UK, a software firm in Oldham, Greater Manchester, made a grovelling apology after Olivia Blands experiences went viralShareCommentsByTim Wyatt:,  JAN NewsOlivia Bland, who was left in tears after the gruelling job interview "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA graduate said she turned down a job after the company boss made her feel like she was back with her abusive ex-partner during the interview. story: NewsHorror moment boy, , is doused in acid in supermarket attack plotted by dadJurors at Worcester Crown Court have been shown footage of the child being attacked at a Home Bargains store in WorcesterShareByRichard Vernalls:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video horror-moment-young-boy-doused-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDramatic video allegedly showing the moment acid was thrown at a three-year-old boy has been shown in court. The child, who cannot be identied for legal reasons, suffered serious burns to his face and arm. His -year-old father is charged with being involved in the attack, which happened at a Home Bargains store in Worcester on July  last year. The dad was involved in a parental custody dispute, jurors heard. A trial jury at Worcester Crown Court was told how the injured child screamed I hurt, over and over again, after being struck.  On Thursday, jurors were shown the stores CCTV video capturing the moment the incident took place. The attack happened in a matter of seconds while the child was standing with his brother looking at toy footballs. The boys dad is accused of conspiring to unlawfully or maliciously cast or throw sulphuric acid on or at the boy, with intent to burn, maim, disfigure or disable the minor, or do grievous bodily harm. Prosecutors allege the father, stung by his we walking out on him and taking the children in April , enlisted others to attack the youngster in a bid to win more contact with the child by painting her as an unfit mother. As the clip was played, the boys father, sat in the dock, held a tissue to his face. Facing the same charge are Adam Cech, , of Farnham Road, Birmingham Jan Dudi, , of Cranbrook Road, Birmingham Norbert Pulko, , of Sutherland Road, London Martina Badiova, , of Newcombe Road, Handsworth, Birmingham Saied Hussini, , of Wrottesley Road, London and Jabar Paktia, , of Newhampton Road, Wolverhampton.  They all deny the allegation. In his opening last week, Jonathan Rees QC, for the Crown, said the boys mother had driven to the store with her children at about pm to buy a party gt. Roadside CCTV played in court showed her being followed by a silver Vauxhall Vectra, allegedly containing Cech, Dudi and Pulko. At .pm she and the children went inside the store, followed shortly after by the three men, with shop CCTV showing Cech approaching the victim. Both youngsters were gazing at a brightly coloured display of footballs at the end of an aisle. The victim could then be seen pointing up at the balls, with his sibling doing practice kicks, as a man in a white T-shirt, identied without dispute in court as Cech, walked past the victim with his arm extended and an object in his hand.  As Cech exited the frame, the victim could be seen looking quickly back towards him before running to his mother nearby. Mr Rees told jurors: What you have just seen is that person in a white T-shirt - you can just catch the moment where the arm is extended. That really is the hub of this case. That is the acid attack. It is over in a split second. You have, in shot, Mr Cech - theres no dispute of that - extending his arm, out towards the child. Mr Rees added: His mother was a short distance away as the attack is carried out, and the sister heard the victim scream out, I hurt, I hurt, I hurt. The boy suffered a cm burn to his left forearm, and a cm burn on his forehead, which needed specialist hospital treatment.  The Crown have also claimed that Hussini, Pulko and Badiova were involved in an aborted attempt near a school, eight days prior to the shop attack. Witnesses were so concerned about the trios suspicious activity they took photos, which have formed part of the prosecutions case. On Wednesday, jurors also heard for the first time how the father sent an image with the text Nailed It! to an alleged co-conspirator, hours after his son had been injured. Running through details of contact alleged between the accused, Mr Rees said cell-siting of mobile phones showed Dudi, Cech and Pulko leaving the area near Home Bargains, immediately following the incident. Phone call log evidence is alleged to have shown that Pulko called Paktia, before Paktia then rang the boys father - some  minutes after the attack.  It is alleged that Pulko then met up with Paktia somewhere in the Birmingham area at about .pm. About an hour later, cell-siting showed Paktia and the fathers phones were back in the Wolverhampton area, Mr Rees told jurors. The Crowns QC then drew the jurys attention to what he described as some stickers being sent with mots and images, from the victims father to Paktia, later that evening. The first showed a cartoon image of what appeared to be a deer, leaning over and comforting a tearful fox.  Mr Rees said: At .pm, hesends Paktia a sticker. One animal comforting a fox which has its head in its hands. And then, the second is sent, a minute after that first one, again to Paktia. It is a sticker which features a young lady in it with the mot Nailed It!. The trial continues.
