title: mackie s offers sweet take on burns night scran
story: Back by popular demand, Mackies of Scotland is relaunching its limited edition haggis and marmalade ice cream for Burns Night.The handcrafted speciality recipe – which has been made on the firms Westertown family farm – is available all weekend at Mackie’s . parlour in Aberdeen.The Burns Night treat will be available all weekendAt am this morning, piper Robert Reid from Deeside Caledonia Pipe Band piped the haggis ice cream in to the Marischal Square parlour.The ice cream has been made with Scotland’s famous Hall’s haggis, and has orange marmalade swirled through the mix.In celebration of Scotland’s Ploughman Poet, customers at . will be given free samples of the experimental dessert – and those who play a tune on the bagpipes will be able to enjoy any free scoop of their choice.Yvette Harrison, Parlour Manager at Mackie’s ., said: “While Marmalade is not a traditional accompaniment for Haggis – we added a ripple to help make this Scottish delicacy a little tastier when served cold in ice cream. And, of course a nip of whisky can also be drizzled over the top to raise a cone to the Bard.“Our haggis ice cream was such a hit last year that we just had to bring it back for Burns Night . Since last year’s limited edition batch, we’ve had people visit the parlour specically to try the flavour. So this weekend is the perfect opportunity for those who didn’t get the chance the first time round to satisfy their curiosity – and their taste buds.”Mackie’s is encouraging the public to share their thoughts on the creation with the hashtag #taemackiesicecream.Yvette added: “We love experimenting with our flavours at Mackie’s, and in celebration of Burns we’re challenging everyone to step outside their comfort zone, and try a scoop of our latest creation."data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Brian McKandie"  Pensioners injuries were "worst" Detective had ever seenviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Singer, radio and television presenter Aled Jones MBE will perform a live set at the event"  Charity to mark th anniversary with celebratory Ball viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: thainstone goes electric
story: ANM Group has installed electric vehicle charging facilities at Thainstone Centre as part of its green strategy and wide-ranging customer service offering.Charging an electric vehicle at the site will be free to all users for the next  months.ANM Group received funding from Transport Scotland, through a programme managed by the Energy Saving Trust private organisations can apply for grant support to install a publicly-available charging points through Transport Scotland’s ChargePlace Scotland project.Home-owners who own or use an electric or plug-in car can also apply for grant support towards the installation of a home charging unit.Grant Rogerson, Chief Executive at ANM Group, said: “We are pleased to partner with Transport Scotland by installing four electric vehicle charge points at Thainstone. “The centre is located just off the A and is a natural choice for the charging points, with a large car park and an award-winning restaurant on site, it has all the necessary amenities for drivers and passengers.“The charge points have the capability of charging up to eight vehicles at one time, and will certainly benefit the local community and those travelling.“The project is in line with our green strategy and supports our business objective of increasing our services to our members, customers and the local community.“We look forward to welcoming all visitors and invite them to see what our centre has to offer.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Brian McKandie"  Murder trial jury to consider verdict viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: travelling after brexit how it impacts data roaming and driving abroad
story: It could be you have concerns aboutyour flight will still take off or what you need to doyou are driving in Europe.Travel company First Choice and ABTA, the leading association of travel agents and tour operators, have released details in a bid to help travellers.Will flights still go evena deal isnrsquot reached First Choice said: ldquoWe know that flights taking off in the UK will still be permitted to fly within the European Unionrsquos airspace, even it a deal isnrsquot reached - thatrsquos been confirmed by the European Commission.ldquoEvenwe have a no-deal Brexit, flights between the UK and the EU will still take place as normal. Even when a deal is decided, nothing will happen overnight - wersquoll go into a period of transition for two years up until late .Read more: What will Brexit mean for you and your family  What aboutIm driving while on holiday For those that choose to drive abroad ABTA says that those with a full UK driving licence may need to apply for a relevant International Driving Permit.These cost £. and are available directly from the Post Office - the RAC and AA will not be issuing them from February .There are two IDPs depending on which country you are visiting - drivers travelling between dferent countriesmay need both types.ABTA said: ldquoThe Government is working to extend the network of Post Offices where you can apply for an International Driving Permit, and has plans to roll these out in more branches across the UK from  February .ldquoCheck carefully which permit is required for each country you intend to drive within, as you may need more than one permit to comply with the law.You may also need a green card. title: what is martial law and why might it be introduced after brexit
story: It could be introduced in the UK to try and stop any riots that break out after we leave the EU on March .But what is martial law and how does it work Martial law - officially called the Civil Contingencies Act - is the imposition of direct military control, to help deal with war, terrorism, or an emergency that threatens serious damage to human le or the environment. Martial law gives authorities a range of powers - they could stop public rallies, impose curfews, limit movement and travel, and confiscate or destroy property. The law also allows government to change other laws to protect people orthey need to make sure we have access to money, food, water and fuel supplies.The emergency regulations are usually only brought into force for a short period of time.Do you have any Brexit-related questions  Email gemma.jimmison@jpimediadata-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.carricktoday webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The guest speakers at Ayrshire Colleges Girls Into Construction and Civil Engineering day"  Girls learn about civil engineering jobsviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.carricktoday webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Will Brexit affect your travel plans "  Theres just  days to go - will Brexit affect your travel plans  viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "CARR | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "CARR | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeThursday  Jan  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Thursday  Jan  : PM

title: christmas tree collection reminder
story: Orkney Islands Council is reminding folk that their Christmas tree collection service for households on the Orkney mainland, within mph areas only, will get underway from Monday next week.The limited collection for real trees will be carried between Monday and the following Friday, February .The intention is that trees collected will be recycled at the council’s Bossack waste facility, along with other garden waste left at recycling centres around Orkney, to produce a fine soil conditioner.Therefore anyone using the tree collection service is urged to take extra care that all tinsel and decorations are removed from their trees.The soil conditioner can be picked up free of charge, subject to availability, from the Council’s Household Waste and Recycling Centres at Bossack in Tankerness, and Hatston, in Kirkwall.Collections fall on normal refuse recycling collection days and will take place as follows:Area  — Kirkwall : Monday February Area  — East Holm, Deerness, title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. title: council website overhaul set to begin
story: newsCouncil website overhaul set to beginJanuary ,  at : pmA comprehensive makeover of Orkney Islands Council’s website is about to get underway, says the authority.The council says that the aim is to modernise the current design, which is more than  years old, and ensure the site is easy to access on a wide iety of devices.The council website offers a wealth of information about the organisation and the services it provides. The new-look for the site is designed to make the user experience simpler, clearer and faster. Its development was shaped with the help of feedback from, among others, the Orkney Opinions public consultation group, students at Orkney College UHI and council staff.OIC is currently developing new ways for people to do more business with the council online and the site will have a key role to play in this.Starting this month, the site will be changed page by page until the overhaul is complete. Public access to the website will not be affected while the work is underway.The site can be found here:  www.orkney.gov.ukcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: the essence of orkney photography competition last chance to submit your photos
story: There are only days until the deadline to submit entries for our Essence of Orkney photography competition.We#ve had plenty of entries for the competition, which has asked photographers of all skill levels to submit images that capture the essence of Orkney in the winter and which bring a fresh perspective to island le, but there is still time to submit photos to our special viewing gallery.The gallery allows people to submit images, check out the competition, cast their vote and share the top images to gather support. We have asked for images that move away from the iconic imagery of Orkney and offer a new narrative.We are delighted to have teamed up with The Pickaquoy Centre for a special exhibition of the absolute best of the bunch.Fteen shortlisted entries from across the three categories will be on show at the centre in February, and the public will be able to vote by ballot on the top five in the People#s Choice Category.The deadline for submissions is Thursday, January  and the exhibition will run from February  to March .Winners of the competition will be announced at the launch of the  Orkney Islander magazine at the end of March, following on from the exhibition at the Pickaquoy Centre.The top prizes include ferry tickets, camera equipment, vouchers and more.Visit www.essenceoforkney to submit your entry, and don’t forget to share the link on social media to boost support for your work!copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Bid for 60k funding as Dingwalls Puffin Pool limps along
story: AN urgent pound, fundraising campaign to enable essential repairs at an ailing hydrotherapy pool used by thousands of people suffering painful or disabling conditions has been launched.The charity-run Puffin Pool in Dingwall has been forced to close its doors on several occasions and is currently ldquolimping along, says its board which is urging people to support an appeal to keep it open.It provides specialist therapy to adults and children with conditions affecting their joints, bones, muscles or neurological system and is also used to help speed up rehabilitation after accidents and operations.But the pool has had to close several times due to the failure of the air handling unit.Board member Barbara Manson said it needed a major overhaul including a new ultra violet system for the water purication system and replacement entrance doors.ldquoIt is limping along until we can get new equipment, she said. ldquoItrsquos the fact the pool is  years old and everything is beginning to break down. We are also very aware there needs to be some internal structural alterations.Given the urgency, the board is using its capital reserves to order the new air handling unit which is should be installed in March.ldquoIf the equipment breaks down between now and then, the pool will have to close, Mrs Manson said. ldquoSome people attend the pool on a weekly basis and that is what keeps them going. If it has to close for a number of weeks, it can make a real dference to their mobility and pain control.Retired GP Helen Charley, board chairman, said:ldquoHaving been a GP in Cromarty for  years, and having needed both hips and knees replaced, I am all too aware of how vital the Puffin Pool is to the good health and wellbeing of so many patients like me, she said.Established in  by Dr Malcolm Stevens, the pool has provided an average , sessions each year over the past four years. They are supervised by qualied supervisors and leguards.The majority of income is from its charity shop In Tulloch Street and the fees which are kept affordable for those on benefits, pensions and low incomes although these have increased by  per cent.Supporters are rallying to support the appeal and staff plan a -mile sponsored walk from Tain to Dingwall.To donate, see www.puffinpool or pop in to the pool or shop.Thursday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Bid to get folk behind Dingwall improvement project
story: BUSINESSES keen to help regenerate Ross-shirersquos county town are being asked to show their support by getting surveys paving the way for a new development project lodged within days.The Dingwall Means Business group is behind plans for a business improvement districtwhich could mirror the success of a similar scheme in Inverness.BID manager George Murray said the group was now ldquowell into its year of listening and talking to all businesses in and around Dingwall to promote a lsquoyesrsquo for BID for the town.He said: ldquoNearly  surveys have gone out and we are still looking for a few more to be ed. The success of the Dingwall BID depends upon our local businessesrsquo support.ldquoWe are working hard to gather information from all the businesses in Dingwall and we need to hear from everyone. This is your chance to have your say and add to the overall business plan. Then all you have to do is vote yes in the ballot and we can make these projects happen.ldquoWe really want to make sure that nobody is missed and that everyone gets their opportunity to vote because this could be a monumental time in our townrsquos history. This could become the year when Dingwall businesses take control over the townrsquos economic future.Mr Murray said: ldquoWe are aware that there must be a decenton their investment. I believe Highland Council currently collect a wee bit more than pound million per annum from non-domestic ratepayers and Irsquove calculated that the levy would need to be between . to three per cent.ldquoThis would allow us to invoice the council for approximately pound,. Itrsquos also possible we would be able to almost match fund this figure from other sources. This would be an amazing amount banked in Dingwall to be spent on Dingwall. This is how we would fund the five-year plan ready to start after a yes vote.He wants remaining surveys, seeking feedback from businesses to a number of questions, ed by Friday, February .Survey results will then be collated with a five-year business plan set to be drafted by the end of March. A yes no vote on BID would then be held in May.Gordon McIntosh, practice manager of Munro  Noble, is a director of BID Inverness and believes the scheme can pay idends for Dingwall too.He said ldquocoach ambassadors had brought more tourists into the city, increasing spend. It meant local businesses were stakeholders in any centre development plans and have the ability to lobby the council over issues of interest. The scheme also paved the way for successful events such as classic car shows, Easter egg hunts and bar and business awards.He said: ldquoWith representatives from a cross section of businesses on the board the strong advocacy we have provided has achieved some notable results. These results have been for the betterment of our business and social community. A healthier, connected community drives profit opportunities.Thursday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Blind Strathpeffer mum set to see her first book published
story: A STRATHPEFFER mum struck blind by diabetes has written a childrenrsquos book after being snapped up by a London publisher.Emily Grayrsquos paperback, Priscilla the Pig, was inspired by her mother Heatherrsquos childhood stories at Woodlands Farm in Dingwall.The -year-old University of Highlands and Islands literature student lost her sight after being diagnosed with Type  diabetes. ldquoIt came as a shock because there was no family history of diabetes, she said.Ultimately she could no longer walk around without help ndash a massive shock to the system.Forced to drop her music studies degree course at Edinburghrsquos Napier University, she admitted the experience was ldquohorric.Getting help from Sight Action ldquowas a massive help. Guide dog April came into her le and the following year she gave birth to her first child, Harris.During pregnancy she mused over her own childhood settled into writing her first story using a voiceover computer programme. Itrsquos illustrated by self-taught Nairn artist Sarah Jane Cumberford.The full-time mum has a lot on her plate and now relies on her main sense of hearing.She said: ldquoLuckily Irsquove got a very noisy little boy. Itrsquos easy to keep track of him. I can generally tellhersquos getting up to no good.A former pupil of Strathpeffer Primary and Dingwall Academy, she said: ldquoIrsquom on a mission to show people that itrsquos not the end of the world and you can still achieve anything you want. ldquoEmilyrsquos book is published by Olympia Publisherson Thursday under her pen name, Madeline Rose.Thursday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Business masterclass aims to put Highland entrepreneurs ahead
story: ENTREPRENEURS will learn how to create and sustain a competitive advantage at an event in Inverness next month.Professor Eleanor Shaw, executive director of the Hunter Centre for Entrepreneurship and vice dean of Strathclyde Business School, will deliver a masterclass on February  and  at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness.The event, which includes a networking dinner, is organised by Highlands and Islands Enterpriseas part of its entrepreneurship programme.Prof Shaw said: ldquoBy creating a competitive advantage, businesses can set a buffer between them and their competitors in turn creating a more secure place in the market.ldquoThe way in which we approach executive education at the University of Strathclyde is dferent ndash we put the focus on the participant in the room, looking at their needs and providing access to toolkits and learning so after the masterclass they can start working with colleagues and honing their value proposition straight away.ldquoEverything we do has been road tested by working with entrepreneurs and wersquove learned that creating a competitive advantage can help a business in many ways.ldquoIrsquom really looking forward to working with Highlands and Islands entrepreneurs, sharing our learnings and making new connections in the region.Louise MacDonald, senior entrepreneurship manager at HIE, said: ldquoCreating and sustaining a competitive advantage can be dficult in todayrsquos ever-changing and dynamic environment.ldquoBusinesses need to think strategically and be able to analyse their proposition to find ways to enhance impact, value and performance.ldquoThe masterclass will teach entrepreneurs from across the region the tools and techniques to stay ahead of the game.For more information, email entrepreneurship@hient or visit www.hie masterclassesThursday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Evanton project branches out with new building
story: COUPLES looking to tie the knot amidst naturersquos splendour will soon have a quirky new wedding venue to consider thanks to a major feat of engineering currently taking place within an Easter Ross woodland.The building currently under construction in Mags Wood near Evanton will also provide an ideal location for yoga sessions for those keen to get back to nature as well as ceilidhs and other community celebrations.Being carried out under the auspices of Evanton Community Woods, the building project may well result in the UKrsquos biggest freestanding reciprocal roofed structure, a simple, strong self-supporting technique perfect for round buildings.Simon Harry, education co-ordinator at Evanton Community Woods, explained how he had been aware of the need for another building within the woodland to provide the many groups already visiting the area more space within which to carry out their activities.He said: ldquoWe aim to run workshops such as green woodworking and outdoor learning from the space along as well as offering it to local groups such as guides and scouts to use for overnight expeditions.ldquoWe have also held a number of weddings in the woods and this would be a perfect location once completed.ldquoThe main driver for the project is that we are also training folk in the unique skills of log building, to share the skills. We have worked with local volunteers, school groups, young offenders, dementia groups, local walking groups and adult learners.In tune with the sustainable development ethos of the group, logs for Mags Wood build have been sourced locally and dragged to the site by Tarzan, a French-bred horse trained for forestry operations ndash and something of a visitor attraction in himself, hugely popular with the school groups who visit the site from time to time.The building project has been able to call on the expertise of local log building expert Henry Fosbrooke, project co-ordinator David Smith and a local volunteer, Don Fraser, who previously worked on the new Queensferry next to the Forth Road Bridge.Mr Harry said that such expertise ldquohas meant that all the measurements done are near perfect.The project has been funded by the Forestry Commission through a community grant amongst ious other sources.Mr Harry said: ldquoThis will be something special for the area and is involving many iniduals and groups in its building ndash truly a community project and something that will last a very, very long time.He is still hoping to find a supplier willing to help with the timber roof cladding required to complete the project, hopefully by the end of March. That would involve around  m x mm larch planks. The alternative will be to process locally sourced timber from the site.Anyone interested in becoming involved or who can help out can contact Simon Harry by email at simon.harry@forest-education or by calling  .Thursday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Ex pat never forgot native Black Isle
story: TRIBUTES have been paid to a former Black Isle man who died at home after battling an illness for several years.Although he moved to Hannibal in Missouri in the s, Kenneth Macdonald, who was born in Fortrose in , retained a lasting interest in his home town, following events from afar through the hugely popular Fortrose and Rosemarkie Past and Present Facebook page.Mr Macdonald shared with that grouprsquos leading light, John Mackenzie, a great interest in motor sports and owned two lovely classic cars, a Triumph TR and a Corvette.Mr Mackenzie said he had decided to use the page to share news of the former Fortrose manrsquos death with others who might have known him. His father ran the family businesses, a coal merchant and a plasterers business in Fortrose.Mr Mackenzie said: ldquoKen ed to his home following a y stay in hospital.ldquoHe was delighted to sit in his own home and in his favourite chair and even smoked a cigarette. Irsquom sure that many of you will join me in offering our sincere condolences to his two daughters Mhairi and Katie and to their families.Mr Macdonaldrsquos late we, Susan, passed away in .During his early years in Fortrose, his budding talents emerged. He studied civil engineering at Edinburgh University and won a bursary to further his studies in the United States at Washington University in St Louis. It was in the States he met his we Susan whom he married in .Mr Macdonald also spent time during a distinguished engineering career in Benbecula during a period when the couple had moved to Edinburgh. There he was working with a contractor who in turn worked for the Ministry of Defence.His elder daughter Mhairi was born during the time they lived in Benbecula.After Benbecula the family moved to Hannibal where Mr Macdonald continued to work as an engineer.He was resident engineer with the Missouridepartment of transportationoverseeing the building of the Mark Twain Memorial Bridge across the Mississippi in the late s.Mr Macdonald continued toto Fortrose when possible but failing health over the past number of years meant that it was no longer possible.His passion for the place he grew up during his formative years was kindled by the local photographs posted on a regular basis on the Facebook page, ranging from present-day scenes to some more nostalgic images.He was also a member of the Hannibal Loafers car club.Thursday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Thursday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Hopes for future of shelved Dingwall fish factory
story: HOPES are high another manufacturer will swoop into Dingwall and start afresh in the building being vacated by the Edinburgh Salmon Company .The base where  people lost their jobs at the end of last month is on sale for an undisclosed sum.Dingwall councillor Margaret Paterson believes the vast majority of the laid off workers will stay put in Dingwall in the hope another venture will open soon.She said: ldquoMany of those people have lived in Dingwall for years and years theyrsquove got staying power, theyrsquore hard workers. Theyrsquove got homes here, their children go to school here theyrsquove made Dingwall their home. You donrsquot leave your home without putting up a really hard fight.Fellow ward councillor Alister Mackinnon understands several companies have been eyeing-up the building but doubts the scale of any future fish processing organisation would match ESCorsquos operation.A spokesman for the firm, which opened in Dingwall in , said: ldquoWe are exploring all possible avenues regarding a potential sale of the facilities.It would not ulge further details, citing commercial sensitivity. Around  workers have been kept on to carry out decommissioning.Before the December closure, more than  people attended a jobs fair in Dingwall Town Hall. Employers in attendance included Stagecoach, Tesco, Marine Harvest, High Le Highland and Highland Council.Highland Council hoped to fill at least some of the  vacant jobs it pitched to the stricken fish workers. Roles included teachers, a social worker, drivers, school cleaners and cooks and a catering area supervisor.It was estimated by Skills Development Scotland, which steered the event, that  jobs were on offer.Kate Forbes, MSP for Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch, said: ldquoThe jobs fair was very successful in terms of attracting a lot of interested employees.ldquoOf course it was a dficult period for them but I hope that the training providers and employers opened up new opportunities for them.ldquoI have had correspondence from at least one attendee since the event.Thursday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Invergordon garden project wins a reprieve
story: A WELL-regarded garden scheme in Invergordon has won a year-long reprieve after two generous donations and a groundswell of public support.Sixteen gardeners with learning and physical challenges work at the project at the Isobel Rhind Centre which has produced stunning hanging baskets for the town. Technip, which has spoolbase at Evanton has stepped in with a pound, donation while Global chairman Roy MacGregor, who had already promised to match fund a crowdfunder, has committed pound, to support the scheme.This gives time for an alternative delivery model to be worked out.Cllr Smith hailed the ldquofabulous news and paid tribute to everyone for their support.Project leader Fiona Grant said: ldquoMy gardeners were all smiles and so relieved that they are going to be able to continue to attend. title: Muir of Ord pupils go purple for inspirational Beth
story: BIG-hearted pupils at a Ross-shire school showed their true colours in a poignant show of solidarity with an inspiratinal "one in a million" classmate suffering from a rare condition.Tarradale Primary pupil Beth Cameron was diagnosed with chronic recurring multocal osteomyelitis , a rare condition affecting around one in a million children in which the bones have lesions, inflammation and pain.Classmates decided to show their support for Beth by inviting pupils to wear something purple last Friday ndash whether that be ribbon, socks, t-shirt or jumper. Beth was greeted by a sea of purple when she turned up at school.Head teacher Tracy Sinclair took to Facebook to explain to parents: "Our perfect Beth is blazing a trail. We talked a lot about barriers to learning and le. Sleeping in. Days off. Lateness. When all the while we have umpteen pupils with so many barriers including severe pain in here every day at nine orsquoclock rain, hail or shine! Wow! Just wow! Our children will tell you spice makes le more interesting! Tolerance and understanding of every human condition makes the world a better place. Your children are trailblazers!"Sheila Scott responded in kind, writing: "So proud of our beautul granddaughter and cant believe how brave and understanding she has been this last  months going through all the pain, tests etc till CRMO was diagnosed and now making others aware of her diagnosis. Always with big smiles and caring for others."Ms Sinclair said: "We agree wholeheartedly. Shersquos a true inspiration."Thursday  Jan  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Walk on the wild side inspires Tain writers new book
story: A FILMMAKER turned author who has drawn on a letime of experiences around the world for his work has been inspired by locations much closer to his Easter Ross home for his latest novel.Tain-based Mike Herd had plenty of time to ponder plots when he worked as a cameraman on more than  films, many requiring endless patience to capture unforgettable footage.His latest novel, The Medusa Shield, is a ldquomystical fantasy set in the fictitious village of Rockburn on the eastern seaboard of the Black Isle. Set in , it sees protagonist Scott and his father James take the car ferry across the Beauly Firth to Inverness as they watch men working on the Kessock Bridge.Scott agrees to attend a farm roup with his father and feels he is being watched by a yellow eye from a dirty painting hanging amongst the lots. Unknown to his father, he successfully bids for it and his le starts to alter in remarkable ways.The action swings between Aberdeen and Florence as Scott embarks on a journey of discovery.Mr Herd, who describes himself as ldquo going on , said time spent alone working on so many films served him.He said: ldquoBy the nature of film work there wasnrsquot a typical day because all trips y. The most memorable film that I have worked on must be Swamp Tigers in the Bangladeshi Sundarbans.ldquoUsing a converted river ferry boat as a mobile base, a typical day would be, rising at four and travelling in the dark to a hide built on stilts embedded in a channel.ldquoI would stay there on my own usually for twelve hours and I did that for months. Being in a hide that long gives you plenty of time to think.ldquoLying awake in bed in the morning, plot ideas and characters nag at me and I have to get up to write about them.ldquoI am a hopeless two-fingered typist which is very frustrating because they canrsquot keep up with whatrsquos going through my head. That aside It does surprise me how easy it is for me to write, I donrsquot know where that comes from. I try to write at least a thousand words a day but quite often Irsquoll hit a brick wall.ldquoI donrsquot worry about that because I know that I will get the inspiration to carry on later.ldquoI try to write about what I know, itrsquos much more convincing and I use locations Irsquove been to. title: tories call on snp to sever links with pro independence blogger
story: The Scottish Conservatives have called on First Minister Nicola Sturgeon to #sever links# with a controversial pro-independence blogger. The Tories have listed those SNP MSPs who follow Jason Michael McCann – known as Jeggit – on social media and criticised the content of his posts, calling them “hate-filled”.Mr McCann has come under particular fire for describing the Holocaust as “fiction” and calling British soldiers in Ireland “legitimate targets”.: Ian Blackford: Scotland must have option to be independent EU nationEdward Mountain, Scottish Conservative MSP for the Highlands and Islands, said: “These views are utterly abhorrent and cannot be excused by the SNP because of his belief in Scottish independence.“It’s clear that Mr McCann’s views are currently supported by a signicant number of SNP MSPs and SNP local branches, despite his obvious anti-Semitism and endorsement of political violence.”In a statement from the Scottish Conservatives, a string of SNP MSPs who follow the blogger, including Christina McKelvie, James Dornan, Angus MacDonald, Gil Paterson, Fulton MacGregor and Emma Harper, were listed, alongside the First Minister’s SNP branch, Southside Central .The statement read: “The children’s minister, Maree Todd, has already been forced to apologise after sharing a message on Twitter calling Mr McCann a ‘great speaker with an important message’.”Mr McCann embarked on a speaking tour of Scotland this week, with an appearance in Airdrie last night before ending the run on  March in Stirling.Mr Mountain said: “Nicola Sturgeon must urgently sever all links between herself, the SNP and this appalling character.“The First Minister must also ensure that all the events promoting this inidual are cancelled, and that the MSPs and her party branches all remove their endorsement.“If the First Minister fails to condemn this inidual’s hate speech, we can only conclude that she, too, endorses it.”: BBC Scotland to screen  referendum documentary on brand new channel Responding to criticism of his online blog entitled the Random Public Journal, Mr McCann told The Scotsman the purpose was to express his right to free speech. He said he had started the blog to speak freely, adding: “I stand by what I have written both as a columnist for iScot Magazine and as the author of my personal blog, the Random Public Journal.“I have said that the collapse of the Good Friday Agreement wouldIreland to violence and this would mean British soldiers will – as far as the armed Republicans see the conflict – be treated as ‘legitimate targets’. “Let me stress again that it is my opinion that no-one should be a target.“As a Christian and a pacist, I do not support or condone violence of any kind. I will not support those prepared to use violence in Irish politics.”Mr McCann said his response to the Scottish Tories was “quite simple”.“Neither Nicola Sturgeon, the democratically elected leader of Scotland, nor the Scottish National Party have any links to me to sever,” he said.An SNP spokesperson warned the Tories to “make sure their own house was in order”.They said: “Maree Todd condemned this inidual’s views as soon as they were brought to her attention – and he is not a party member.“Butthe Tories are intent on trawling people’s Twitter followers they had better make sure their own house is in order.“The SNP’s priority this week is passing a budget to provide extra cash for schools, hospitals and other services, providing some stability amid ongoing Brexit chaos – something the Tories just want to ert attention from.”©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: key snp figures told by nicola sturgeon to prepare for possible election
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...SNP parliamentarians have been told by Nicola Sturgeon to prepare for a possible Scottish electionthe government at Holyrood fails to pass its budget today.The Scottish Government heads into today’s vote without a deal to secure a majority, risking defeat on its spending plans for the coming year.During a meeting of the SNP group at Westminster attended by the First Minister on Monday, Ms Sturgeon warned her MPs that they should prepare for a possible Scottish election campaignthe government fails to get its budget through, The Scotsman understands.However the move comes amid speculation that Ms Sturgeon may need a fresh mandate from the electorate to secure another referendum on independence, as she prepares to reveal her plans on the issue. Publicly, the government has stated that it is focused on getting its spending plans passed and is confident of reaching a compromise.In , when an SNP minority government had its budget defeated by the Scottish Parliament, then-First Minister Alex Salmond threatened a snap election before the deadlock was broken.The current SNP minority has struck a more conciliatory tone and sought to calm speculation about an election, with Finance Secretary Derek Mackay last night appealing for MSPs to “act responsibly”.Last ditch talks are set to continue today in the final hours before a vote, with the Green Party holding out for concessions on local government spending and council tax reform.Mr Mackay must secure the support of the six Green MSPs to pass his budget, with all other opposition parties committed to voting against it.Green Party co-convener Patrick Harvie has dismissed suggestions his party could bring down the government by rejecting the SNP’s budget as a “myth”.But senior Nationalist figures were openly speculating about the possibility of an election earlier in the week, with SNP committee convener Gillian Martin warning Green MSP Andy Wightman on social media that voting down the budget could force an election and put a second Scottish independence referendum at risk.“You’ve seen the way the other parties coalesce against us to try and bring down the government,” Ms Martin posted on Twitter. “Since  everything for them is about defeating the pro-Indy Parliament.”She added: “We are at risk of an election that might see pro Indy parties lose seats and put us in a weaker position.”Polls show the SNP remains in the lead in Scottish Parliament voting intention, but that the nationalists have lost ground compared with their performance in the  Holyrood election where they narrowly lost their majority.Scottish Conservative shadow finance secretary Murdo Fraser claimed uncertainty around the budget showed the SNP were “unfit” for government.“The SNP has neglected the day job so badly that it’s now struggling to get the single-biggest responsibility taken care of. Nicola Sturgeon is so resigned to the weakness of her own administration, she’s been forced to rally the troops for another election.“Hers would be the first government in the history of the Scottish Parliament to call an election because it couldn’t pass a budget.“That would be a shameful legacy, and shows just how unfit the Nationalists are for government of any kind.”Scottish Liberal Democrat campaign chair Alex Cole-Hamilton MSP said: “We’ve made clear to the SNP that we want a budget that focuses on education, mental health and local government funding.“If their inability to get a budget through necessitates a new Scottish Parliament election then I have every hope that people in Scotland will want to use that to eject the Nationalists.”A Labour spokesman said “no credible anti-austerity party would propose” the draft budget put forward by the SNP.With no deal last night, Mr Mackay said: “Our spending plans for the coming year contain additional money for schools and hospitals, protecting vital public services and investing in our economy, while also providing stability amid the ongoing uncertainty caused by Brexit. “With that backdrop in mind, there has never been more need for MSPs, of all parties, to act responsibly and not add to that uncertainty.”Mr Mackay added: “We are open to compromise in order to ensure we deliver the Budget that the country expects.” ©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: alex salmond unique case is not unprecedented says advocate
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Many people are asking whether Alex Salmond, with his major public profile, could possibly get a fair trial in Scotlandany charges proceed.Many people are asking whether Alex Salmond, with his major public profile, could possibly get a fair trial in Scotlandany charges proceed.If challenged, the court’s answer will be considered in the context of the publicity around the allegations. To date no case in Scotland has been stopped because of prejudicial publicity and that’s despite there having been some high-profile cases that attracted considerable, sometimes extremely prejudicial, media attention.These cases were dferent in that the accused were not well-known public figures, but it was argued that publicity about the allegations could prejudice any trial.I wouldn’t call this case unprecedented, but it has its own unique aspects. However, the challenges for the court have been considered before. Two examples are the trial of William Beggs for what became known as the “Limbs in the Loch” murder, and that of Nat Fraser, who was accused of killing his we, Arlene. There had been a great deal of reporting about the cases and the courts had to decide whether fair trials could be achieved. In both situations, the courts decided the cases could proceed fairly, referring to the safeguards of the passage of time between any publicity and a trial the focusing effect for a jury of listening to the evidence and the strong directions given to a jury in such cases to decide only based on evidence they hear in court.Those representing Salmond may argue that he is uniquely well-known and that some allegations against him have, to an extent, been canvassed in the media. They may say that it will be almost impossible to find jurors who have never heard of him. But that doesn’t matter – more to the point is whether it will be possible to find jurors that are untainted by prejudicial knowledge about the allegations.The Crown will say Contempt of Court rules apply and no-one can now publish anything that might prejudice the trial. There is now signicant protection in place and the media can only really report on procedural aspects such as the fact he has been charged.Very senior people at the Crown Office will be involved in decisions about possible proceedings once they have seen all statements and reports. Meantime, everyone on social and all other media must observe our strict rules about reporting live cases.John Scott is a QC Solicitor Advocate and president of the Society of Solicitor Advocates©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: scottish budget set to pass after snp and greens deal
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...Scottish workers face new charges for parking at work along with steep hikes in their council tax bills under a budget deal struck between the SNP and Greens.The budget was branded a “triple tax whammy” by opposition parties last night, while business leaders warned it would erode the trust of industry. The deal with the Greens, which was confirmed less than an hour before finance secretary Derek Mackay addressed MSPs, also saw the SNP break a manesto pledge to cap council tax rises at  per cent. The agreement meant the £ billion Scottish budget was passed at stage one.Mr Mackay said: “These additional measures will deliver the most signicant empowerment of local authorities since devolution and provide additional funding to support local services.“This enhanced package offers up to £ million of increased funding and flexibility to councils, on top of the £.bn local government settlement. In total, overall spending power for local authorities next year will be £m higher than it is currently.”The deal will mean £m of additional cash for councils and the ability to raise £m more amid concerns over cuts in Mr Mackay’s original plans.: Insight into the frantic last-minute negotiationsCross-party talks are also to be staged by ministers with a view to replacing the council tax. If agreement can be reached, legislation will be published by  to bring about this change. However, any replacement would only be implemented after the next parliament in .The relaxation of the  per cent cap on council tax rises is a breach of a manesto pledge by the SNP to cap the rate at this level. It means bills can rise by a maximum of . per cent. In Edinburgh, this will mean the average band C property goes up by £, while band G properties rise by £. Councils will also be handed powers to introduce a new workplace parking levy, although this will not include hospitals and other NHS properties. Although the costs remain unclear, a similar scheme in Nottingham costs firms £ a yearthey have  spaces or more. It is up to the firms whether or not they pass the charge onto staff.As well as the plastic bag charge increase, ministers have also agreed “in principle” to a charging regime for disposable coffee cups.The tourist tax was immediately welcomed by Edinburgh Council leader Adam McVey, who immediately indicated the levy would be introduced in the capital.“I’ll keep speaking to industry to make sure we get this policy right,” he said.Councillors in Edinburgh will discuss the plans again next week. They have suggested a surcharge of £ on hotel rooms, which could raise £.m a year.The Scottish Tourism Alliance said the tax would “deliver a signicant blow to our industry”. The body said: “It will only serve to undermine the confidence that the thousands of tourism businesses operating across all sectors of the industry has had in the Scottish Government.”Andrew McRae, the Federation of Small Business’policy chair in Scotland, slammed yesterday’s deal.“We’ve seen concessions from the Cabinet secretary for finance that will erode the small business community’s trust in his administration,” he said. “Instead of Brexit help for firms, we see more tax changes, including a levy on our vital tourism industry. Ministers repeatedly promised firms that they would not pave the way for tourism taxes without industry support. They’re breaking that promise.”Town halls will also be handed control over rates relief on empty commercial properties, which would be another avenue to generate extra funds.Ministers have also pledged to set out three-year funding deals for local authorities in future so they are not left in the dark from year to year as they seek to plan spending.Gail Macgregor, resources spokeswomen with local government body Cosla, said the measures set out by the government were welcome recognition of the “essential services” councils deliver.“This helps councils across the country in making their tough choices,” she said.“Meaningful progress has been made on a number of fronts, including a commitment to secure more sustainable funding for local government going forward.”Councils had originally complained the budget plans set out by Mr Mackay in December would have meant £m of cuts to their “core budgets”.Tory finance spokesman Murdo Fraser said the deal left Scots facing a “triple tax bombshell”.He said: “We will pay the highest income taxes in the UK, council tax will go up and now you might even be taxed hundreds of pounds a year for taking your car to work.”The SNP minority government needed the support of at least one other party to get its spending plans through. Labour had pledged to vote against the plans over the extent of the cuts to local councils, while the Tories and Liberal Democrats were both demanding a second referendum be taken off the table.It meant the Greens, who have combined with the SNP for the past two years to back the budget, were again Mr Mackay’s only serious hope of a deal. Two days of negotiations had failed to resolve the impasse, but an agreement was finally reached at the th hour.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: uk to benefit from 31bn eu japan trade deal for just 57 days
story: A deal expected to boost trade between Europe and Japan by almost  billion eurosa year and save EU companies up to one billion eurosa year in duties comes into effect on Friday.The UK will participate in the EU-Japan Economic Partnership Agreementfor just  days before its scheduled departure from the European Union on March .Campaigners for a second Brexit referendum said the EPA highlighted the advantages to the UK of remaining in the EU and the need for the public to be asked again whether they want to leave.International Trade Secretary Liam Fox predicted in  the UK would be able to replicate up to  EU free trade deals for “a second after midnight” on Brexit day.So far none are believed to have been formally signed.Former business secretary Sir Vince Cable, a leading supporter of the People’s Vote campaign, said: “The EU’s trade deal with Japan took years to negotiate and runs to thousands of pages but British business will worry that they might only enjoy the benefits for a few weekswe crash out of the European Union in March.”The Liberal Democrat leader added: “We were told it would be the easiest thing ever to leave the European Union but this deal shows that there is no form of Brexit that fulfils the promises made for Brexit.“Losing access to this trade deal will leave the UK with a worse deal than we already have inside the EU.“For Britain to sign its own trade deal with Japan will take Liam Fox years, and meanwhile the uncertainty will go on and on for British business, costing this country jobs, skills and investment.”Labour MP Jo Stevens, a supporter of the Best for Britain campaign for a second referendum, said: “The EU and Japan between them make up one-third of the world’s GDP.“We’re about to lose access to all this. We are sleepwalking towards a disaster and the Prime Minister needs to wake up and step up.“The advantages of remaining in the EU are growing, not diminishing. It’s time to end the nightmare that is Brexit.”After years of negotiations, the EPA was finalised in  and signed last July, creating the world’s largest bilateral free trade zone, covering  million people.It removes the majority of the one billion eurosof duties paid annually by EU companies exporting to Japan and eliminates a number of non-tarf barriers to trade.Japanese duties of .% on European cheeses, such as Cheddar, will be scrapped and the EU will be able to increase beef exports to Japan “substantially” and sell processed pork products duty-free, the European Commission said.The agreement also opens services markets in the areas of finance, e-commerce, telecommunications and transport and facilitates EU companies’ access to procurement markets in  large Japanese cities.In addition, the protection of geographical indication status will be extended to hundreds of speciality EU agricultural products for sale on the Japanese market.European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker said the deal would “turbo-boost” trade and give customers in both markets greater choice and cheaper prices, while providing “gold standard” protections for workers and the environment.“Europe and Japan are sending a message to the world about the future of open and fair trade,” said Mr Juncker.“We are opening a new marketplace, home to  million people and almost a third of the world’s Gross Domestic Product, bringing the people of Europe and Japan closer together than ever before.”Japan’s Prime Minister Shinzo Abe visited Downing Street on January  for talks in which Theresa May said both sides had expressed their hopes for an “ambitious bilateral arrangement, building on the deal already agreed between Japan and the EU”.Shuichi Akamatsu, minister for economic affairs at the Japanese Embassy in the UK, said: “We intend to steadily implement the EPA and further deepen the collaborative relationship between Japan and the EU.“With regard to Brexit, the Japanese government continues to urge both the UK and the EU to secure predictability and legal stability in the process of Brexit, and is watching with great interest in order that the impact on Japanese businesses, as well as the world economy, should be minimised.“When Prime Minister Abe visited the UK last month, he himself earnestly told Prime Minister May that Japan would like a no-deal Brexit to be avoided.“As reconfirmed during the bilateral meeting between the leaders of Japan and the UK, after the UK’s departure from the EU, Japan intends to build swtly on a new economic partnership with the UK using the Japan-EU EPA as a basis.”A Downing Street spokeswoman said “good progress” was being made on a number of trading arrangements to replace the free trade deals that will be lost when the UK leaves the EU.The spokeswoman said there were “strong elementswhich we think could be replicated in our own deal with Japan.”Japanese companies employ around , people in the UK and trade between the two countries totalled £ billion in the past year.Major employers such as Nissan and Honda, which invested in the UK as a gateway to the European market, have voiced concern about the potential impact of Brexit.©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings
